text: here's a quick tip for tapping holes and
soft materials like plastics tapping
normally takes kind of a long time by
hand so I came up with a much quicker
way using a drill so what I have here is
a quarter inch hex to 3/8 drive square
adapter and I chuck that up and then
here is a tap wrench with a 3/8 square
drive this is made by Irwin there might
be other companies that make these and
it's currently holding a number four tap
440 tap the other trick is that for soft
materials using a bottoming tap even to
start your hole is actually a good idea
the taper taps and the plug taps kind of
gum up and melt the material instead of
chopping through so a bottoming tap
takes a bigger bite at first and doesn't
melt as much you'll probably have to use
coolant so this is just distilled water
and I'll put a drop of water on the hole
and
in there that hole is tapped so it's
about 5 to 10 times faster than doing it
by hand and I'll be able to tap all
these holes in much less time than doing
by hand and then when you're done I'd
like to just chamfer the hole a bit with
a six-foot countersink like that and
blast that's a very cleanly tapped hole
